    One-Sample Binomial Problems

    2021-03-08

    OneSampleBinomial.Rmd

    Introduction

    This article/vignette provides an overview of functions considering designs for one-sample binomial outcomes. All routines use exact calculations for sample size and power. The underlying probability model is that we sample independent binary (Bernoulli) observations with probability of a successful outcome (hereafter referred to as response) equal to \(p\). The general design problem is rule out a null hypothesis \(H_0: p=p_0\) versus an alternative \(H_1: p=p_1\) where \(0< p_0 < p_1< 1\).

    • nBinomial1Sample(): compute power or sample size for fixed (non-group sequential) design
    • gsBinomialExact(): compute boundary crossing probabilities for a group sequential design
    • binomialSPRT(): derive a design using the sequential probability ratio test (SPRT)

    Fixed Sample Size

    Suppose we have a random variable \(X\sim\hbox{Binomial}(n,p)\) where \(n\) is the number of independent observations of independent binary random variables with probability of a response equal to \(p\). Consider two response rates \(p_0 < p_1\). Without loss of generality, we can assume the null hypothesis response rate is \(p_0\) and the alternate hypothesis response rate is \(p_1\). We set a sample size \(n\) and a critical value \(b\) such that if \(X\ge b\) then we reject the null hypothesis \(H_0:p=p_0\). Type I error is by definition

    \[\alpha=P(X\ge b|p=p_0)=\sum_{m=b}^n\binom{n}{m}p_0^m(1-p_0)^{n-m}.\]

    Power is one minus the Type II error

    \[1 - \beta= P(X\ge b|p=p_1)=\sum_{m=b}^n\binom{n}{m}p_1^m(1-p_1)^{n-m}.\]

    For any given \(n,b,p_0,p_1\) it is straightforward to compute these quantities. The critical value \(b\) for a given sample size \(n\) can be computed as the inverse of the binomial distribution. For example, assuming \(n=100\), \(p_0=0.15\) and \(\alpha=0.025\), we can compute \(b\) as follows:

    b <- qbinom(p = .025, size = 100, prob = .15, lower.tail = FALSE)
b
#> [1] 22

    Due to the discrete nature of the binomial distribtuion the actual Type I error is less than or equal to the specified 0.025.

    alpha <- pbinom(q = b, size = 100, prob = .15, lower.tail = FALSE)
alpha
#> [1] 0.02214206

    We note that with one fewer successes, the bound would have great than the desired 0.025 Type I error:

    pbinom(q = b-1, size = 100, prob = .15, lower.tail = FALSE)
#> [1] 0.03927809

    Now we can compute power assuming a given \(p_1>p_0\), say \(p_1= 0.25\).

    pbinom(q = b, size = 100, prob = .25, lower.tail = FALSE)
#> [1] 0.7136299

    A natural question now would be what \(n\) is required for a test of \(H_0: p=p_0=0.15\) against \(H_1: p=p_1=0.25\) if we desire one-sided Type I error \(\alpha=0.025\) and \(90\%\) power. This can be computed with the function nBinomial1Sample() as follows:

    library(gsDesign)
#> Loading required package: ggplot2
nBinomial1Sample(p0 = 0.15, p1 = .25, alpha = .025, beta = .10, n=100:250, conservative = TRUE)
#> [1] 180

    We note that the beta argument is 1 minus the targeted power, or 0.10 in this case. We can check this as above, or more simply by computing power for different sample sizes:

    nBinomial1Sample(p0 = 0.15, p1 = .25, alpha = .025, n=173:182)
#>      p0   p1 alpha       beta   n  b     alphaR     Power
#> 1  0.15 0.25 0.025 0.08457155 173 36 0.02454081 0.9154285
#> 2  0.15 0.25 0.025 0.10861651 174 37 0.01667349 0.8913835
#> 3  0.15 0.25 0.025 0.10103712 175 37 0.01816144 0.8989629
#> 4  0.15 0.25 0.025 0.09388032 176 37 0.01975376 0.9061197
#> 5  0.15 0.25 0.025 0.08713248 177 37 0.02145527 0.9128675
#> 6  0.15 0.25 0.025 0.08077947 178 37 0.02327081 0.9192205
#> 7  0.15 0.25 0.025 0.10370184 179 38 0.01584671 0.8962982
#> 8  0.15 0.25 0.025 0.09647807 180 38 0.01725049 0.9035219
#> 9  0.15 0.25 0.025 0.08965842 181 38 0.01875244 0.9103416
#> 10 0.15 0.25 0.025 0.08322948 182 38 0.02035713 0.9167705

    We note in this table that Type II error beta is below the targeted 0.10 if \(n=173\), but not for \(n=174,175,179\). If we had not used the conservative=TRUE argument above, the sample size selected would be:

    nBinomial1Sample(p0 = 0.15, p1 = .25, alpha = .025, beta = .10, n=100:250, conservative = FALSE)
#> [1] 167

    Generally, given the possibility of overrunning on sample size, it may be good to use the conservative=TRUE option.

    The three columns at the right side of the above table are:

    b: The critical value for the number of responses out of n which will reject \(H_0\). alphaR: The realized (exact) Type I error realized; this will be less than or equal to the input alpha in all cases. Power: The probability of crossing the upper bound \(P(X\ge b|p=p_1).\)
